name: MZ 80B
keyboard: Full-stroke keyboard, 92 keys. Numeric keypad and function keys.
coprocessor: Zilog Z-80A PIO Controller, Intel 8253-Compatible Precision Timer, Intel 8255-Compatible Peripheral Interface
colors: Built-in 9'' monochrome (green) CRT (8 x 8 dot matrix)
ports: Centronics, RS 232c, IEEE 488, 16-bit free programmable I/O card, Floppy interface (all optional)
description:
As the German magazine "mc" reported in its January 1981 first edition, the MZ-80B was shown first on the German Hannover show, in April 1981.
The MZ-80B was one of the nicer, if not the nicer, and well designed home computer ever built. It also featured an innovative 'Intelligent' cassette deck which was able to find and load a program anywhere in the cassette tape. All the cassette functions were remote controlled by software.
 
The MZ-80B was compatible with the other MZ 80x computers (Sharp MZ 80A, Sharp MZ 80K), but unlike these ones, it was possible to have high graphic resolution thanks to one or two optional boards which provided one or two switchable graphic pages.

This computer, like all the computers of the Sharp MZ series, had no language in ROM, Basic (or any other language) had to be loaded from tape.

shot.description: <br><font color="red"><strong>> REAR SIDE</strong></font><br><blockquote>You can see the expansion box outputs. There are three cards in this machine : a home-made DAC card, a centronics card and a floppy disk drive interface.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> TAPE RECORDER CLOSE UP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The cassette recorder uses standard audio cassette tape. The data transfer systems is called SHARP PWM and transfers data at 1800 bits/second.<br>The control is automatic (program) or manual (with dedicated keys on the keyboard).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> KEYBOARD CLOSEUP</strong></font><br><blockquote>The keyboard is pretty good.<br> You can see here the cassette tape deck control keys.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> CASE OPENED #1</strong></font><br><blockquote>This version has 5 expansion cards:<br> <b><font color="blue">(1)</font></b> Parallel interface card<br> <b><font color="blue">(2)</font></b> Floppy disk controller card. Up to 4 FDD could be connected<br> <b><font color="blue">(3)</font></b> Graphics card #2 (2nd. graphics page)<br> <b><font color="blue">(4)</font></b> 32 KB RAM expansion card<br> <b><font color="blue">(5)</font></b> Graphics card #1 (1st. graphics page).</blockquote>
<br><font color="red"><strong>> CASE OPENED #2</strong></font><br><blockquote>Another version with an additional I/O card.</blockquote>

<br><font color="red"><strong>> MOTHERBOARD EXPLAINED</strong></font><br><blockquote><b>(1)</b> Gate Arrays : Display Controler & Char Generator<br> <b>(2)</b> Programable Interface Timer 8253<br> <b>(3)</b> 2KB CG-ROM<br> <b>(4)</b> 2KB V-RAM<br> <b>(5)</b> Monitor Connector<br> <b>(6)</b> CN15 connector (? 80 column / graphic card connector ?)<br> <b>(7)</b> Optional 8KB Graphic Card connector<br> <b>(8)</b> 4bit Binary Decoder<br> <b>(9)</b> LED connectors (RVS/SetGraph/Lock)<br> <b>(10)</b> Keyboard connector<br> <b>(11)</b> Programable Peripheral Interface 8255<br> <b>(12)</b> Cassette connector<br> <b>(13)</b> MZ80-EU Expansion box connector<br> <b>(14)</b> Optional 8KB Graphic card connector<br> <b>(15)</b> 4 x 16KB RAM<br> <b>(16)</b> 2KB IPL-ROM<br> <b>(17)</b> Gate Array : Memory Controler<br> <b>(18)</b> LH0080A (Z80 A by Sharp)<br> <b>(19)</b> Handshake signals connector for peripherals (not connected)<br> <b>(20)</b> PIO<br></blockquote>

item.description: MZ-80EU - Expansion Unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ-80EU - EXPANSION UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>This module holds up to 6 expansion cards, and is inserted in the rear of the MZ 80B.<br> It is connected to the motherboard.<br> You can see four cards connected : a home-made ADC card, a MZ-8PB5I centronics card, a MZ-80GM Hi_res graphic card and a MZ-80FI floppy disk interface. </blockquote>

MZ-8PB5I Printer Interface Card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ-8PB5I PRINTER INTERFACE CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This card provides an interface for a centronics-compatible printer.  </blockquote>

MZ-80GMK Hi-Res Graphic Card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ-80GMK HI-RES GRAPHIC CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>The MZ-80GMK is connected to the MZ-80GM card (graphic card plugged directly on the motherboard). It provides an enhanced display (320 x 200 x 2 bitplanes).</blockquote>

MZ-80FI - Floppy Disk I/O Card||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ-80FI - FLOPPY DISK I/O CARD</strong></font><br><blockquote>This card allows connection of the MZ-80FD/FB/FBK Floppy Drive Units (or any FDD which uses a Ferranti MB-8866 controler).  </blockquote>

MZ-80FD - Dual 5.25||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ-80FD - DUAL 5.25</strong></font><br><blockquote>This external dual-floppy drive is connected to the MZ-80FI interface card (fitted in the expansion box), and provides 2 drives (286KB).<br> Disk Geometry : 70 tracks (35 double-sided), 16 sectors, 256-Bytes per Sector.   </blockquote>

French FDD unit||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> FRENCH FDD UNIT</strong></font><br><blockquote>Instead of selling the original Sharp FDD unit, the Sharp French subsidiary (Sharp Burotype Machines) preferred to made their own unit. The case could hold up to 4 drives. The drives were Canon models.</blockquote>
MZ 80P3 - Dot Matrix Printer||||||<br><font color="red"><strong>> MZ 80P3 - DOT MATRIX PRINTER</strong></font><br><blockquote></blockquote>

emulator.name: Michael Franzen's multi emulator
emulator.description: Multi system emulator ( 80K/A, 700, Spectrum, TRS80, ZX81, Coleco, and others )
